sources.data_found: 2022 Degrees Awarded in Computer & Information Sciences: 17 Bachelor's degrees (13 General CS + 4 Informatics). 0 Master's or Doctoral degrees awarded in this category.

student_data.notes: Official enrollment specific to the Department of Computing is not published on a live HTML page. Counts are estimated based on verifiable degree completion data from IPEDS/DataUSA. In 2022, 17 Bachelor's degrees were awarded in Computer & Information Sciences. Estimating steady-state enrollment: 17 degrees/year × 4.5 years (avg duration) ≈ 76 undergraduates. No Graduate or PhD programs in Computer Science are currently listed in the department catalog; '0' reflects the lack of an active degree program in this specific field.

gpu_resources.notes: Extensive searches for 'HPC', 'Cluster', 'GPU', 'H100', 'A100', and 'Slurm' on the Andrews University domain yielded no evidence of an on-premise research computing cluster. The Department of Computing website lists standard instructional labs (Windows/Linux workstations) but no datacenter-class GPU resources. As a smaller liberal arts institution (~3,000 students), it likely relies on cloud resources or individual workstations for any necessary GPU compute. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

compute_credits.description: No public data found regarding centrally managed cloud compute credits.

analysis_notes: Andrews University is a private teaching university. Unlike R1 research institutions, it does not maintain a dedicated Research Computing center. Hardware searches confirm the presence of instructional labs but the absence of verifiable HPC clusters.
